awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Long Term Adaptation to Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies the relationship between climatic degradation, conflict, and emergent complexity in Chumash society on the Northern Channel Islands and adjacent mainland coast. Previous research has identified substantial reorganization of labor, development of new technologies, and punctuated increases in lethal conflict within Chumash society during the Medieval Climatic Anomaly (MCA), a period of episodic droughts and fluctuating sea-surface temperatures (SST). Very little is known about Chumash social organization and marital patterns prior to Spanish contact, and archaeology is well-suited to reclaiming this knowledge. This research will identify kinship patterns in Chumash society during the MCA by using an innovative combination of archaeogenomic (ancient DNA) and archaeometric (strontium, carbon, and nitrogen isotopes) analysis of ancient Chumash burials. Minimally invasive small tissue samples were taken from ancestral remains under the supervision of the Barbareño Band of Chumash Indians. Resulting data will be contextualized with climatic records for the region and will enhance our understanding of how environmental change affected human social organization over the past two thousand years. This research will substantially aide archaeologists in understanding nuanced ways in which society changes in the context of climate change. The researcher’s indigenous Chumash heritage provides a unique opportunity for this research to positively impact both the Native American and scientific communities. Goals of the proposed research include introducing a diverse array of Native American perspectives within archaeology and development of pedagogical methods to help integrate archaeological research within tribal communities as a form of historical knowledge. Integrating ancient DNA and isotopic method within indigenous archaeological practice serves as a foundation for transformational change between indigenous and academic communities while stimulating important discourse surrounding the future of minimally destructive analysis of indigenous remains in North America. 

The project will evaluate and add to models broadly focused on how humans respond to short and long-term environmental change and how these changes affect human social organization. This research takes place on the Northern Channel Islands and the adjacent Santa Barbara coastline, areas that have been continuously occupied by the Chumash people. Significant changes in Chumashan society co-occurred with a series of episodic droughts known collectively as the Medieval Climatic Anomaly. This study will couple genome-wide sequencing with stable isotope data from Chumash burials and compare these data to regional climate records to reconstruct changing familial relationships and social structure through time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Information regarding Chumash village composition, marriage patterns, mobility, and socio-political structure primarily come from brief accounts by the Spanish or from mission records. These records are often juxtaposed with the last 13,000 plus years of Chumash history in the Channel Islands region of California and try to work backwards from Spanish contact. A goal of this research was to address changing social structure by working in the past and identifying how that past structure developed into what was encountered by the Spanish. While research utilizing aDNA and stable isotope analysis is not new, the questions answered by this collaborative research are incredibly important to both archaeology and the Chumash community. Initially, radiocarbon dates suggested these village sites were occupied during the Medieval Climatic Anomaly and abandoned before the arrival of Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo in 1542. New developments in radiocarbon dating and the opportunity to respectfully analyze my ancestors’ remains and directly date them shows there are multiple occupations spanning roughly 1200 years. The village of Niaqla/ Nəmkəlkəl was thought to have been abandoned prior to Cabrillo’s arrival in the Santa Barbara Channel, but this research shows occupation began prior to Cabrillo and continued up until the Island Chumash were coerced into the missions in 1818. This research is an important case study looking at how the social structure and economy of the Island Chumash was eroded by introduced diseases and waves of Spanish explorers, the Manilla Galleons, and Missionization. 

Most importantly, this research provided the opportunity to relearn and reawaken aspects of our Chumash culture that were previously dormant due to colonialism, from our ancestors themselves. It also aides in decolonizing a narrative of our people built from synchronic datasets derived from Missionization and brief Spanish encounters of the Chumash. This research was built alongside other members of the Chumash community from three different Chumash tribes and has evolved between its inception and its completion. It has provided opportunities to take Chumash community members out to the Channel Islands to visit various locations of our homeland previously unavailable to the public. Through this research, community members have been able to meet and develop projects with other institutions, agencies, and even other tribes. Its completion and subsequent publications will reflect the many voices that helped make this research possible. 

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Brian E Holguin
